Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/17/2003 5:48 PM by karunphilip

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Many points in my message are overlooked and you concentrate on the one thing that was least important, though most sloppily made by me.

What I meant is that some of the things on your site are meaningless. Like conscious-size and what-not. I do not use terms like that because no one would understand what I was getting at. With an external model, we have something that can be discussed meaningfully.

See, with a mathematical model of sentient linguistic neural networks, we could then implement the theory in an analog machine, and get a machine that tells us it experiences blue, and may even be able to spit out the neural patterns that correspond to that experience. And maybe we can even build a machine that will be able to spit out our own patterns corresponding to each experience. But all we can say is ok, i don't know how the machine feels that experience (and cannot know it) but I have my experience, and have the fact that the machine also claims an internal experience in the same way I do.

At this point we *would* have a mathematical model of sentience, the knowledge that some patterns are produced for each experience, and our subjective internal view of the psychological internal feeling.

The point is, that my particular architecture I threw out is to ask questions like: ok, is perception basically the perception of difference? i.e. blueness is a physical property of some objects and therefore causes certain psychologicla experiences of it in our minds. Blueness defined as different from redness, greenness and other different colors. To ask, is my creativity basically a process of applying analogy -- learning one abstract method or relationship in one field and applying it to another? To ask, is my knowledge fallible? But these questions arise because the mathematical model proposed claims that sentience can be implemented using that architecture. And progress on understanding our own psychology and internal conscious experience becomes possible.

Mathematics is a tool. I think it can be used to help our understanding of consciousness, but only by uniting the external and internal thru working out how a neural net could do things that we do. And there are many things we do besides meditate on our psychological experiences -- things that we can communicate better with. At the end, yes, we do not know whether the machine truly has conscious experiences like ours, but you cannot know whether I truly have experiences like yours either, or vice versa. So what?

And by the way, what philosophical lessons there are to be learned from either consciousness studies or quantum mechanics is nothing but tp explicitly incorporate necessary fallibility of theories in all theories themselves. Instead of acknowledging and incorporating this rationally, people dance around with all kinds of confusion like multiple universes, mental monism and the like.

Regards,

Karun.
--
Karun Philip
Author: Zen and the Art of Funk Capitalism: A General Theory of Fallibility

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 5:09 PM by blue_is_not_a_number

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Many points in my message are overlooked and you concentrate on the one thing that was least important, though most sloppily made by me.


This "one" thing happened to be the reference to my homepage. What do you expect? ;-)

What I meant is that some of the things on your site are meaningless. Like conscious-size and what-not. I do not use terms like that because no one would understand what I was getting at. With an external model, we have something that can be discussed meaningfully.


"Conscious-size" is the quantifiable aspect of consciousness, that which come closest, I assume, to your definition of a "substitute" for consciousness. It is the shapes and sizes and color-data (as opposed to color-experience) that appear in the 3D-image which we see consciously.

See, with a mathematical model of sentient linguistic neural networks, we could then implement the theory in an analog machine, and get a machine that tells us it experiences blue, and may even be able to spit out the neural patterns that correspond to that experience. And maybe we can even build a machine that will be able to spit out our own patterns corresponding to each experience. But all we can say is ok, i don't know how the machine feels that experience (and cannot know it) but I have my experience, and have the fact that the machine also claims an internal experience in the same way I do.


Sounds like an advanced tape-recorder to me.

At this point we *would* have a mathematical model of sentience, the knowledge that some patterns are produced for each experience, and our subjective internal view of the psychological internal feeling.


Not at all, far from it.

The point is, that my particular architecture I threw out is to ask questions like: ok, is perception basically the perception of difference? i.e. blueness is a physical property of some objects and therefore causes certain psychologicla experiences of it in our minds. Blueness defined as different from redness, greenness and other different colors. To ask, is my creativity basically a process of applying analogy -- learning one abstract method or relationship in one field and applying it to another? To ask, is my knowledge fallible? But these questions arise because the mathematical model proposed claims that sentience can be implemented using that architecture. And progress on understanding our own psychology and internal conscious experience becomes possible.


"Blueness" in the context of discusions of consciousness is commonly used to use the specific conscious (psychological) experience that we have when we something that we call "blue". Let us say you are in room and you take a very carefull look around, and then close your eyes. Ther might be a short after-image, but you wait until that is gone, too. For a certain amount of time, you will still have a pretty good idea where everything is. Imagine that our sensory apparatus would continously update this "pretty good idea", this knowledge, and we would always know where everything is, without seeing it in color.

Now, the fact is that in contrast to this situation, we _do_ see things in color, consciously. That is an additional, meaningful fact. That is a crucial component of consciousness.

Mathematics is a tool. I think it can be used to help our understanding of consciousness, but only by uniting the external and internal thru working out how a neural net could do things that we do. And there are many things we do besides meditate on our psychological experiences -- things that we can communicate better with. At the end, yes, we do not know whether the machine truly has conscious experiences like ours, but you cannot know whether I truly have experiences like yours either, or vice versa. So what?


It is correct that I cannot know whether you have conscious experiences, and that is an important fact. However you know that you have conscious experiences at all (if you do ;-)), whereas a machine does not have any means to tell whether it has conscious experiences as long as this machine is functioning as expected from an "objective" (third-person-perspective) theory or concept.

And by the way, what philosophical lessons there are to be learned from either consciousness studies or quantum mechanics is nothing but tp explicitly incorporate necessary fallibility of theories in all theories themselves. Instead of acknowledging and incorporating this rationally, people dance around with all kinds of confusion like multiple universes, mental monism and the like.


Sounds almost like James Randi or so. Do you have some kind of issue with awareness? Would you not care about happiness because you might not be able to prove to me, objectively, that you are happy?

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 5:57 PM by karunphilip

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]


>Not at all, far from it.

Looks like we are talking at each other now -- I am taking the position that the internal and external are two sides of the same thing, and you are simply denying it.

>Now, the fact is that in contrast to this
>situation, we _do_ see things in color,
>consciously. That is an additional, meaningful
>fact. That is a crucial component of
>consciousness.

And it is a crucial part of physical reality. The component of consciousness you want to study is a small fraction of what can be studied about sentience. And you aren't getting anywhere with it at least not in the way that I know what you're getting at apart from being aware of my psychological experience, which I have been aware of since I was a kid.

>It is correct that I cannot know whether you
>have conscious experiences, and that is an
>important fact. However you know that you have
>conscious experiences at all (if you do ;-)),
>whereas a machine does not have any means to
>tell whether it has conscious experiences as
>long as this machine is functioning as expected
>from an "objective" (third-person-perspective)
>theory or concept.

I don't think you followed the thought experiment. The machine has language and tells us that it *does* have experiences that correlate with what we are talking about when we talk about our consciousness. So machine also "knows" it has consciousness and claims as much.

>Sounds almost like James Randi or so. Do you
>have some kind of issue with awareness?

Why do you think I would have a problem with awareness? I think I am aware of my psychological experience, and alsso aware of the room I am sitting in. Are you aware of both, or does one not exist in your opinion?

>Would
>you not care about happiness because you might
>not be able to prove to me, objectively, that
>you are happy?

I don't care particularly about happiness -- I treat happiness as a choice. One can choose to be happy during the toughest times and be sad even when most things are going right. I choose to be happy most of the time, or at least balanced. It is awareness -- being awake, as the Buddhists say -- that brings such equanimity. But you need to be aware of your physical existence as much as aware of your psychological experiences. There is no need to discard either, and no advantage whatsoever in doing so.

Regards,

Karun.

Karun Philip
Author: Zen and the Art of Funk Capitalism: A General Theory of Fallibility
http://www.k-capital.com

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 6:34 PM by blue_is_not_a_number

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Looks like we are talking at each other now -- I am taking the position that the internal and external are two sides of the same thing, and you are simply denying it.


Denying what? Do you expect to repond to everything at the same time? Let me then focus now on the "two sides of the same thing" concept, feel free to bring anything else back into the discussion when you feel that is required.

If you are saying the third-person-perspective and the first-person-perspective are two sides of the same thing, I would assume that it means, given your other statements, that the third-person-perspective would be a complete account of everything that happens.

This would, logically, mean that what happens "objectively" is independent of any additional "conscious" perspective. However, when we make physical statements that, for example, we see colors consciously, we do so based on the fact that there is an additional perspective. We don't say that because we are programmed to say it, or because we would say it anyway for any other reason, but because we know it is true. We say it because it is a fact. Therefore the third-person-perspective is not independent of the first-person-perspective, as it would have to be if they were just "two different sides of the same thing".

So, in the acknowledgement of everything I've heard on this subject, this theory fails in the light of available facts.

This is not impacted by the possiblity of creating a machine, computer or tape-recorder or something else, to claim consciousness regardless of whether it is present or not. (As the whole idea of a "machine" is that it functions purely based on third-person concepts.)

It is also not impacted that we need to make abstractions before making verbal statements, although these are certainly possible sources of error, as in the sentence "I vividly see the color blue", probably the only word that _directly_ refers to an emperical reality is the word "blue".

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 6:58 PM by karunphilip

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

I think the problem here is that you have an incorrect idea of what objectivity is. No theory is complete, and no theory *can* be complete since logic itself shows that Goedel's Theorem and Lucas' corllary are true. Let us look at your actual statements though, because I think there are further leaps of logic.

>If you are saying the third-person-perspective
>and the first-person-perspective are two sides
>of the same thing, I would assume that it means,
>given your other statements, that the third
>person-perspective would be a complete account
>of everything that happens.

No, no theory is complete. The theretical design, when implemented, will take an enormous amount of engineering "fooling around" by testing and re-designing. The design also is not completely observable. We will not be able to predict what choice the machine would make, nor would we know after the fact why it made a choice. Even simple (non linguistic) nerual net programs exhibit this behavior -- I've built several. In an analog parallel system this is definitely going to be the case. The design is a meta-learning device. We simply create a machine to observe and detect differences, and create words for the categories that emerge. Once its set off, we won't be able to know where it will go or what it will learn.

>This would, logically, mean that what
>happens "objectively" is independent of any
>additional "conscious" perspective. However,
>when we make physical statements that, for
>example, we see colors consciously, we do so
>based on the fact that there is an additional
>perspective. We don't say that because we are
>programmed to say it, or because we would say it
>anyway for any other reason, but because we know
>it is true. We say it because it is a fact.

Beware of fallibility. We say it because we think it is a fact. And it may be. The conscious perspective though, is a part of the process. It is very much there.

>Therefore the third-person-perspective is not
>independent of the first-person-perspective, as
>it would have to be if they were just "two
>different sides of the same thing".

Why would such independence be necessary? The consciousness process of the machine is a part of its design. If we are simply a physical object similarly constructed then we *would* indeed have internal conscious experience and hey, look, we do.

>This is not impacted by the possiblity of
>creating a machine, computer or tape-recorder or
>something else, to claim consciousness
>regardless of whether it is present or not. (As
>the whole idea of a "machine" is that it
>functions purely based on third-person
>concepts.)

Every machine actually built takes more than what science tells us. Every engineer will tell you that and that is why they sometimes joke about pure scientists as being in an ivory tower. In your own field of programming, its like saying that a system must be completely specified before you will implement it. A real, experienced programmer knows that no matter how hard you try, the specs evolve, get fuller in detail as you progress. If the spec was truly complete, the spec would be the program. But in programming you are producing programs -- a fininte state machine. With analog engineering, you are producing a non FSM.

>It is also not impacted that we need to make
>abstractions before making verbal statements,
>although these are certainly possible sources of
>error, as in the sentence "I vividly see the
>color blue", probably the only word that
>_directly_ refers to an emperical reality is the
>word "blue".

Yes, but my image of a rose refers directly to the rose in front of me. The point is if you use the fact that it is not actually the rose that's in my head, then the same argument applies to your abstraction. You are left in nothingness. Which is not a bad starting point -- it was mine for my current theory. At that point, you can laugh at the notion that you doubted whether there was a rose even though you saw a conscious image of one, and start to live in the real world instead of your Matrix.

Regards,

Karun.
--
Karun Philip
Author: Zen and the Art of Funk Capitalism: A General Theory of Fallibility
http://www.k-capital.com

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?

Karun,

OK, you are not denying the physical universe. I think I was conflating you with Peter Lloyd, whereas I know you have questioned him as well -- my apologies. You are saying that there is more than the physical universe (namely consciousness). But saying there is more to the physical universe than any known theory about the physical universe means there is more to the physical universe than current theories show. So why do we need "more than the physical universe"?


It depends on the definition of "physical". Also for reasons of verbal expression, I lately preferred to use "physical" in the specific (limited) sense of the current scientific understanding that reality functions (idealized) according to third-person quantitative (mathematical) laws of physics only (causally-closed, self-contained).

Consciousness may be (and I think is) a part of the process, and the internal experience is entirely predicted if we are physical creatures constructed similar to my brief high level architecture.

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/19/2003 6:50 PM by karunphilip

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

I lately preferred to use "physical" in the specific (limited) sense of the current scientific understanding that reality functions (idealized) according to third-person quantitative (mathematical) laws of physics only (causally-closed, self-contained).


That view of physical reality died with logical positivism. Unfortunately they still teach that approach in high school and you don't get to the meat of it unless you study philosophy of science and critical rationalism. Theories are thought of more like maps in a critical rationalist framework. And they are not considered infallible.

Karun.

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/19/2003 7:32 PM by karunphilip

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

So how would you describe the relationship between "maps" and "reality" ? More epistimologically? I think I would know what you mean with "infallible", though.


Start with Kuhn's comparison of Newton's theory and its displacement by Einstein. Was Newton wrong? His formulae are still used for general mechanics. But there cannot be an instantaneous force of gravity because nothing can be faster than light. His formulae were good approximations of the cosmos (like a decent but imperfect map) but failed to predict Mercury's orbit accurately. Einstein fixes that and provides a "better map" which allows us to acccurately predict Mercury's orbit and other things. Einstein's theory also fails to explain some events, and we are in the midst of looking for the answers. Sooner or later, one will be found, if science progresses.

And how would you describe the character of these maps? Aren't they still "(idealized)" "third-person quantitative (mathematical) laws of physics only (causally-closed, self-contained)" ?


The theories are idealized, but reality is "dirty". Even Kant got that right so many years ago, though CPR is very hard to read. That the universe is self contained is still a part of the assumption. And the internal view of neural processes that are percieving and generating language models (and more abstract models by abstracting from the words themselves) is what consciousness might be (probably is). It is predicted by the idealized theory of neurally generated langague, and it is obviously felt by us. Could be this theory is wrong, but it could be right. So it is untrue that no third person idealized (mathematical) model can be used to model sentience, and we could safely assume that consciousness is the internal view of this process. We need nothing else.

Regards,

Karun.
--
Karun Philip

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/19/2003 7:57 PM by subtillioN

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Just a quick note:

His formulae were good approximations of the cosmos (like a decent but imperfect map) but failed to predict Mercury's orbit accurately.


Mercury's progression was not predicted by Einstein; it was "explained" by him. To do so, he used Newtonian (not relativistic) time in his general relativity equations.

The "confirmations" of Einsteins Relativity are not nearly as solid as we have come to believe in our mythologizing of History. The Special Theory of Relativity, as it turns out is quite superfluous.

Einstein's theory also fails to explain some events


Yes, like the mechanism of gravity. It simply provides the tautology of the rubber sheet analogy which still uses gravity (unexplained) to cause the object to gravitate down the incline of the indented sheet. We still have no understanding of how empty space can be curved. What does the curvature really map? Sorce Theory provides those answers and more...

=)

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 7:15 PM by sequoia

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Blue believes in no Hooluvoo.

Try to imagine a super-intelligent shade of blue. Silliness. SomeTHING can be intelligent AND blue, but that is not a true hooluvoo.

Blue, Searle, etc point out that the SUBJECTIVE experience of consciousness (which we all feel) stands apart from the objective world we inhabit. Chatterbots frequently claim to be conscious. My pet AIBO acts conscious, but I don't believe that either of them are capable of the SUBJECTIVE experience of pain or happiness. They cannot CHOOSE to be happy, because that choice is not and can never be available. My AIBO certainly ACTS happy, sad, frustrated and upset at times. But I don't (and neither do you) believe that it subjectively experiences these things.

While I don't agree with Blue's perspective, denying subjectivity will not help our arguments.

And, to stay on topic, I'd like to add that this dualistic universe may be the reason the AIs need humanity to survive in the Matrix movie's universe. The AIs, for all their computational power, are still limited by their incapacity to feel choice, bridge that divide between computation and subjectivity. They are deterministic to their cores.

Not to imply that I personally am a dualist.

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 8:03 PM by blue_is_not_a_number

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Blue, Searle, etc point out that the SUBJECTIVE experience of consciousness (which we all feel) stands apart from the objective world we inhabit.


Neither Searle noe myself belive that it stands apart. (Besides, I'm not a Searle-ist.).

What I think _does_ stand apart are the _concepts_ we have about the "objective" world (such as the mathematical laws of physics): they stand apart from the conscious world we experience. There is only one world: our life, which includes the universe (in the sense of the theory of relativity).

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 8:25 PM by sequoia

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Neither Searle noe myself belive that it stands apart. (Besides, I'm not a Searle-ist.).

What I think _does_ stand apart are the _concepts_ we have about the "objective" world (such as the mathematical laws of physics): they stand apart from the conscious world we experience. There is only one world: our life, which includes the universe (in the sense of the theory of relativity).

[Parent]

Um, okay, but you (and Searle) believe that an insurmountable divide exists between subjective experience and computation, right? I don't understand how this belief can be anything but dualist: you posit that things either have a subjective, conscious state, or they don't. That's two worlds by my count. The alternate view is that everything is computation. A tree is the product of a series of DNA programs, as is a bug or a person. A brain is the product of DNA programs, and mind is the ultimate product, which seems so complicated to us that we generally feel it belongs in it's own category of existence (soul, spirit, etc).

Monist: Subjective mind is, ultimately, computation.
Dualist: Subjective mind is not and cannot be computation.

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 9:15 PM by subtillioN

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

What I think _does_ stand apart are the _concepts_ we have about the "objective" world (such as the mathematical laws of physics): they stand apart from the conscious world we experience.


Of course they do. They are mere quantitative representations. They are simply tools to aid the precision of our understanding. They are not that which they represent. There is a vast (yet functionally irrelevant) gap between representation and reality that can never be spanned.


There is only one world: our life, which includes the universe (in the sense of the theory of relativity).


True, but how is that "in the sense of the theory of relativity"?

SubtillioN: Of course they do. They are mere quantitative representations. They are simply tools to aid the precision of our understanding. They are not that which they represent. There is a vast (yet functionally irrelevant) gap between representation and reality that can never be spanned.


So we have the description of neuronal processes and the reality of neuronal processes. I'm still missing something...what could that be? ;-)

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 10:16 PM by subtillioN

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

So we have the description of neuronal processes and the reality of neuronal processes. I'm still missing something...what could that be? ;-)



So we have the the equation of the "Law of gravitation" and we have the reality of the actual physical process of gravitation.

So we have a recipe for a gourmet meal and we have the actual steaming hot gourmet meal yet the recipe doesn't taste quite like the gourmet meal.

So we have sheet music and we have a symphony orchestra and yet again the sheet music doesn't sound like the orchestra.

So we have the description of the wart on my brothers big toe and we have the real, physical growth, seeds and all.


What is the difference? What are we missing?

Perhaps it is the understanding of the crucial difference between a description of some process and the actual process described. They simply are not the same thing. The description is a structure of language. The actual thing has nothing to do with language. The linguistic description is an abstraction for the sole purpose of squeezing a vast amount of complexity into the tiny human imagination. It will naturally lose a great deal of the vast amount of complexity that it attempts to generalize in this abstraction process.

The difference should be obvious. The description is NOT that which it describes. The universe does not function on "laws". The "Laws of Nature" are merely aids to the understanding of the behaviors of nature. Do you suppose that the force of gravity actually uses Newtons Laws and the inverse square equation? Of course not. Does that make Nature a complete mystery? Of course not.

Do you suppose that to read a description of some state of consciousness that you should be able to *feel* that state?

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 10:32 PM by blue_is_not_a_number

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

So we have sheet music and we have a symphony orchestra and yet again the sheet music doesn't sound like the orchestra.

[...]

Do you suppose that to read a description of some state of consciousness that you should be able to *feel* that state?


An orchestra doesn't really sound like anything either, it just produces air waves. Same goes for neuronal processes. They don't sound like anything either. How would, for example, the descriptions of neuronal processes have anything to do with the difference between sound and color? What they describe are neuronal processes, and that's it. A mismatch of concepts. Whether, and specifically: how, the reality of neuronal processes is related to the reality of conscious experience, that is a completly different question, and requires its own description (if any were possible in quantitative terms at all, which is another question, but we are far away from even asking that one.)

An orchestra doesn't really sound like anything either, it just produces air waves.


You are not seeing the forest for the trees. The point of the analogy was the difference between a description and the thing or process described.


Same goes for neuronal processes. They don't sound like anything either.


If they are constructed and activated in the correct patterns then they produce a representation of sound waves which is *sound* to a sentient being.

How would, for example, the descriptions of neuronal processes have anything to do with the difference between sound and color?


The same way that the descriptions of gravitation and magnetism illustrate key differences between them that actually exist.

What they describe are neuronal processes, and that's it.


That is what produces the sensory and memory phenomenon which is consciousness.

A mismatch of concepts. Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/18/2003 11:55 PM by subtillioN

That's my point. ;-)


Ok so you are admitting that the problem is that you simply can't see the correlation between the description and the thing described.

So do you understand that there must be an intuited correlation between any description and the thing described? If so then you cannot argue further that the problem with consciousness studies is that there is this necessary correlation. This point is rendered moot because the description of ANY process requires the very same type of correlation. If we are to allow your reasoning then we must admit that we can scientifically understand absolutely nothing because ALL scientific knowledge is a description (mathematical or linguistic) and as such necessarily requires such a correlation.

So let's get on to understanding the problems you are having making the correlation between neural processes and consciousness.

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/19/2003 12:31 AM by blue_is_not_a_number

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Ok so you are admitting that the problem is that you simply can't see the correlation between the description and the thing described.

So do you understand that there must be an intuited correlation between any description and the thing described? If so then you cannot argue further that the problem with consciousness studies is that there is this necessary correlation. This point is rendered moot because the description of ANY process requires the very same type of correlation. If we are to allow your reasoning then we must admit that we can scientifically understand absolutely nothing because ALL scientific knowledge is a description (mathematical or linguistic) and as such necessarily requires such a correlation.

So let's get on to understanding the problems you are having making the correlation between neural processes and consciousness.


The correlation between neuronal processes ("measurable-size") and the information appearing within consciousness ("conscious-size") is philosophically obvious and scientifically explorable (although requiring the help of first-person-interviews). However consciousness is more than the information appearing in it.

This should be obvious, as information is abstract, but unfortunately that is the point which many do not find obvious. The conscious experience of "blue" is not just the knowledge of "blue".

The question why certain information is experienced consciously, and why it is experienced in the way that it is experienced, for example, why some is experienced as color, and some as sound, that question cannot be answered by a naive description of neuronal processes.

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/19/2003 1:12 AM by subtillioN

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

However consciousness is more than the information appearing in it.


The way you word this statement leads directly to your homuncular conclusion. If information appears 'within' consciousness as within a television set, then yes the statement would be true and there would still need to be a conscious viewer within the brain to watch the sensory tv-set.

The point is that information doesn't appear 'within' consciousness. It actually *is* consciousness. Consciousness *is* the amalgam of internal and external sensory 'information' (not 1's and 0's) within the memory-trained neural-network architecture of the brain. Consciousness is the simultaneous [and I don't care what Einstein says about simultanaeity! Reality *is* simultanaeity itself! =) ] correlation of all available channels of neural 'information': both internally and externally 'generated'.

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

This should be obvious, as information is abstract, but unfortunately that is the point which many do not find obvious. The conscious experience of "blue" is not just the knowledge of "blue".


Good point. It is true that many people get the theory confused with the reality and it is true that the understanding of the neural processes leading to the experience of the color 'blue' is quite different from the actual experience of 'blue'. That is the whole point isn't it? To generate new objective information to correlate with the subjective information that we are so intimate with? To see both sides of the phenomenon?

The question why certain information is experienced consciously, and why it is experienced in the way that it is experienced, for example, why some is experienced as color, and some as sound, that question cannot be answered by a naive description of neuronal processes.


I am afraid that it can and actually *has*, to some extent, been answered by cognitive science. The fact is that the neural network architecture for the different types of sensory modules is quite different. The obvious conclusion is that differences in neural-sensory architecture lead directly to differences in sensory experience. We still have quite a way to go in explaining why it feels *exactly* the way it does, but there is no fundamental reason that we can't eventually develop reasonably precise answers to such questions.

Do you think that reasonable answers cannot be achieved?

Re: Glitches reloaded: Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/19/2003 6:38 PM by subtillioN

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

You are rejecting the theory of relativity as well?


Yes. It was an erroneous reaction to an erroneous assumption.

It was classically postulated that the ether was a solid with a shear modulus of elasticity no less than that of steel. This is simply because it was erroneously thought at that time that a fluid could not transmit the transverse waves of polarized light. It is now known, however, that a superfluid can transmit transverse waves so the classical assumption that the ether was a solid was not necessary. Had this little fact been known at the time of the Michelson Morley experiment there would have been no need to abandon the ether, which was the conceptual foundation for every field and wave theory at the time. Now that the conceptual substrate has been abandoned there is no understanding of what the wave-nature of matter consists of. It is thought that they are waves of nothingness, or at best of probability, but we all know that probability is a mathematical tool for dealing with large numbers. Large numbers of WHAT? We should ask!

Which areas of physics do you accept?


The equations are fairly correct, but the interpretations are wrong at the core and this error manifests itself all across the board. This error permeates the entire structure of physics going all the way back to the ancient Greek assumption of the a-tom and the void. Sorce Theory takes the alternate route from that ancient metaphysical bifurcation point and postulates that there is no such thing as an a-tom (in the ancient greek sense of fundamental, structureless particle) or a void. The only thing that exists is a continuous, compressible, inhomogeneous, frictionless, variable density substance. A single unified field. There is no such thing as a 'fundamental particle' because particles are not fundamental and there is no such thing as a void because the void lacks the causal complexity required for existence. Continuous, fluid-dynamic substance itself is fundamental to all particles and percieved void.

What was he searching for?


The essence of causation.

He was a devoted follower of Spinoza and it turns out that Spinoza's metaphysics (continuous monistic substance) that he loved so much is the key to the Unified Field Theory (the omni-local, omni-directional, omni-scalar essence of causation) that he was searching for in his deepest metaphysical ponderings of Spinoza's metaphysics.

Re: Behold, Smith as autonomous Agent?
posted on 06/13/2003 3:04 PM by blue_is_not_a_number

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Peter,

(ii) Terms that denote physical things (such as protons) are defined analytically. A proton is defined in terms of fundamental physical quantities such as mass and charge. Those fundamental physical quantities are undefined primitives of physics. Thus the language of physics is a closed formal system that does not make external semantic references.


I am not quite clear what you mean by "not making external references". Our conscious experience reflects events whose occurences have mathematical relationships. In my understanding this means that there are semantic references, although we cannot prove (and do not have to assume if we don't want to) that they are "external". Still, there are semantic references, would you agree?

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/13/2003 5:41 AM by DarrenBooy

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]


What I think is interesting is the choice of avatar used for the digital representation of their physical mind.

It is basically an exact copy of their physical self with a few aesthetic changes. Is this a involuntary reaction of the mind to automatically make a copy of oneself?? Does their mind see their physical body as its identity??

The research I have discovered is when users are choosing an avatar to represent themselves it is rare that they choose an image which represents themselves but instead an image which represents what they want to become.

Does the mirror scene (when the mirror is crawling up Neo's arm) represent the 'mind' self embodying??

Also, Morpeus states 'The body cannot live without the mind'. Is he implying that the digital representation of the mind is really the acutally representation of the mind, if you relate the above to this context??

One interesting idea I had is what would happen if a member was under the influence of hallucengenic drugs. How would he/she see themselves then?? Would the matrix still be the same?? Would feelings of being able to fly etc. be transferable to the matrix so the influenced does actually fly.

Enough heavy footed sweeping statements for one day I think!!

Darren Booy

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/13/2003 6:40 PM by PeterLloyd

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

What I think is interesting is the choice of avatar used for the digital representation of their physical mind.


Neo does not choose his avatar in the Matrix. He is plugged in as a baby. His avatar grows as his physical body grows in the pod.

It is basically an exact copy of their physical self with a few aesthetic changes.


But don't forget, it is almost certain that what is presented as the 'real world' in 'The Matrix' turns out to be a Meta-Matrix in 'The Matrix Reloaded'. (We know this because Neo stops the sentinels with his hand.)

Most likely, Neo as a baby is assign identical avatars in both the Matrix and the Meta-Matrix.

Is this a involuntary reaction of the mind to automatically make a copy of oneself??


He has no choice over his original avatar in the Matrix. In the training construct, and when Neo goes back into the Matrix, it makes sense to re-use the avatar body form that he is familiar with.

Does their mind see their physical body as its identity??


Yes, unless they have spent years in Hindu or Buddhist meditation.

The research I have discovered is when users are choosing an avatar to represent themselves it is rare that they choose an image which represents themselves but instead an image which represents what they want to become.


Might be relevant to the Agents ...

Does the mirror scene (when the mirror is crawling up Neo's arm) represent the 'mind' self embodying??


No, it is a hallucination causes by Neo perceiving that he is actually immersed in goop.

Also, Morpeus states 'The body cannot live without the mind'. Is he implying that the digital representation of the mind is really the acutally representation of the mind, if you relate the above to this context??


I think he is implying that the virtual heart and lungs of the avatar require actual signals from teh actual brain.

One interesting idea I had is what would happen if a member was under the influence of hallucengenic drugs. How would he/she see themselves then?? Would the matrix still be the same?? Would feelings of being able to fly etc. be transferable to the matrix so the influenced does actually fly.


I don't hallucinogenics can exist in the Matrix. The Matrix is very likely limited to sensorimotor I/O. It is not wired to generate hallucinations.

Peter B Lloyd

PS These points are expanded in the ebook:
http://www.ursasoft.com/matrix/exegesis.htm

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/16/2003 11:28 PM by sequoia

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

"Have you ever had that feeling, where you're not sure if you're asleep or awake?"

"All the time. It's called mescaline."

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/17/2003 4:03 AM by PeterLloyd

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

"Have you ever had that feeling, where you're not sure if you're asleep or awake?"

"All the time. It's called mescaline."


You're right, thanks.

So, some possibilities are:

(a) The Matrix is not after all limited to accessing the sensorimotor nerves, but has electrodes throughout the brain. When someone takes a hallucingenic drug such as mescalin, the Matrix activates parts of the nerve tissue so as to reproduce the effects. (Since hallucinations are even more private than normal perceptions, however, the Matrix would have even more freedom in deciding how to render the hallucinations.)

This is not a favoured hypothesis, because the scene where Neo first leaves the pod and clearly has a functioning sensorimotor cortex proves that the Matrix has, throughout Neo's life, been stimulating those parts of his brain. And, for any purposes other than tripping on psychoactive agents, those sensorimotor wires will be sufficient. Would the Matrix architect have invested in a vast increase in technological complexity justs so that the people in Matrix can use recreational drugs? Unlikely.

(b) The Matrix keeps on tap a range of psychoactive substances, ranging from caffeine, mescaline, beta blockers, to LSD. When someone in the (virtual) Matrix world takes a drug, the relevant actual drug (or a close approximation) is released into the physical body of the person. Recall that there are a lot of tubes going into Neo's body, not just the brain's bioport.

This is an attractive possibility, but still supposes that the Matrix architect built up a substantial facility for (i) manufacture and quality control of the pharmaceutical agents, and (ii) distribution of the drugs to human bodies, synchrnised with the avatar taking the drug inside the Matrix world.

Again, I don't think the Matrix architect would think it worth while. Also, there is a risk of drug addiction, drug baron wars, deaths, and hence loss of human crops.

Moreover, if (as I have suggested elsewhere) the Matrix is using the spare capacity of the human brains as a bank of parallel coprocesssors, then they would not want real psychoactive substances sloshing around.

(c) When someone takes a psychoactive drug, the Matrix feeds in sensorimotor signals from a *another* VR world, a sort of virtual dream world. This could probably be derived from the normal Matrix world just be loosening up the constraints, so that eg people could fly.

This is the most likely hypothesis IMHO.

(d) The Wachowski's fluffed it. The film is inconsistent. Unlikely. Clearly they have thought about this issue because they have given consideration to the related questions of the red pill in 'The Matrix' and the chocolate cake in 'The Matrix Reloaded'.

BTW There is a related question over the truth serum that the Agents give to Morpheus. Of course, it cannot directly affect Morpheus' brain, because the injection is only vitual. It can only affect his perceptions.

Thanks for this correction. I'll amend the ebook accordingly. (http://www.ursasoft.com/matrix/exegesis.htm)

Peter B Lloyd

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/18/2003 7:36 PM by sequoia

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

I figured hallucinations were produced by programs (pills) that muddled or enhanced sensory input provided by the matrix. "Drug" programs could even instruct the matrix to cross signal paths (synesthesia), or overstimulate the limbic system, understimulate frontal lobes, etc.

While the hallucinogenic "drugs" may (or may not) do little actual harm to the physical body, the matrix would likely have an interest in keeping those "drug" programs illegal. The health of the matrix likely depends on the full functioning (and predictability) of individual minds.

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/20/2003 9:27 PM by zardoz

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]


The health of the matrix likely depends on the full functioning (and predictability) of individual minds.


Does it really? Remember, humans are used as sources of energy; so as long as their bodies still function (and I presume that the AIs have remedial means to sway people back from destructive ends), they're all set.
Also, consider the fact that drugs, their illicit nature and their potential for addiction are all addditional layers of control that the Matrix provides. Particularly, if you consider that it can probably tailor the reaction; so, instead of 'freeing' the mind, it can enslave it further.

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/20/2003 9:36 PM by zardoz

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]


I don't hallucinogenics can exist in the Matrix. The Matrix is very likely limited to sensorimotor I/O. It is not wired to generate hallucinations.


Why not? I would be more likely to assume that the Matrix is capable of affecting the human mind and body, since it has indirect access to it through the bioports.
The ability to produce hallucinations would be an effects means of control and programming.

But beyond that, consider the fact that temporal lobe seizures are induced by abnormal electric impulses in this portion of the human brain.
(from: http://health.yahoo.com/health/encyclopedia/001399 /0.html)
"[...]As the temporal lobe is involved in processing emotion and sensations, seizures in this area may begin with feelings of fear, feelings of joy (sometimes with religious associations and the sensation of a "presence"), recall of certain music, or smells and other unusual symptoms.[...]"

All the Matrix would have to do is stimulate the temporal lobe appropriately.

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 06/19/2003 11:34 AM by zardoz

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

This is in response to the sidebar, but since there is no specific discussion area for this, I will post a comment here.

When Neo learns hyperkinetic kung-fu, his brain makes fresh connections to those lines, and he learns what signals to send down those lines to make his avatar stronger and faster. Over time, he acquires more skill in issuing instructions to the Matrix on those lines.


The treatment of the bioport is perhaps the most reasonably and completely argued of others I've seen posted so far. However, one has to wonder just how many additional neural connections the implant can support and whether or not this is the most efficient means of affecting the Avatar. While the analogy to a parallel port is apt, I would go further and suppose that the intrusive neural implant behind it is extremely complex, is the repository of the human's Avatar code and the machinery/code to control it. All humans that can interface with the Matrix are instructed in utero virtuo about how to access this implant; so that when they are older they can perform in the simulation without conscious awareness of this feat. A more efficient means, and one that Neo (and other Zionists) consciously learn to control, is how to influence the code in the implant at a more direct level. As all of the Buddhist references allude to, there is no 'body' in the Matrix, only mind. As such, one can decouple oneself from many of the limitations of the physical world (and as a quick note, there is no reason to assume that the AI's designed the Matrix with a completely realistic physical model, just one that was internally consistent) and perform feats far beyond those in the real world. Neo-as-uber-hacker eventually learns not only to suppress certain coding/signal transmissions, but to influence it directly, giving him extra-oridinary powers and one of the reasons why the Architect is so keen at downloading this information into the System.
I don't suspect that the Architect was entirely forthcoming with Neo; there are undoubtedly other reasons why it (and the AIs) developed the Matrix in the first place. It's not unreasonable to assume that the machines are on their own little quest to better themselves, but having hit an evolutionary wall they need to introduce an additional, non-rational function to their programming, hence the near-infinite permutations of the Matrix and the evolution of the One. And why they need to download the One's code; each iteration with the previous One's code incorporated gets them closer to an Answer.

Another self-consistent explanation of the Trilogy
posted on 06/22/2003 3:14 PM by zardoz

[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

By looking at the initial story (I recommend you to see Animatrix) machines were banned from human society because of an event (to preserve its own existence an "house robot" killed its masters not respecting the Asimov's rules) that woked up human conscience and that begun a war against the machines.

So...

The Matrices were both build by the machines at "01" and its basic design is to keep human in a "quiet sleep" while energy is being sucked up by those bionic implants plugged in the human bodies.

Now... why a reboot?

remember that were all sort of matrices before the one Neo was plugged into, and there were always someone who could bend the "rules" and escape from the "dream" and realize reality...
those were the "One" from the prophecy...
So I guess that the "Matrix" created that cyclic program to assure that there are still plenty humans plugged into the system by creating a false sense of freedom into one of them.
The rebooting would create a new matrix so Manking couldn't realize that they were stuck in time... at the 90's



Re: Glitches Reloaded

I dont buy that.

IMHO both worlds are the Matrix, build by humans in order to create strong AI.

What constitutes strong AI is the ability to make choices. The other times they tried the AI programs (called the one) the program did as the architect predicted, but Neo didn't, he made a choice that even the architect couldn't predict.

Why is the Oracle able to forsee what he is going to do next, because Neo (the AI) is a program so she would be able to read Neo before he could read himself (the delay that creates the self acording to varius experiments)

Neo lived unaware of what he really was in the first Matrix, they then help him realise that the illusion he has been living in is not real. But neither is the "real" (zion world), and that is why Neo is able to stop the sentinels and why Smith doesen't get killed by them and why you can talk about a reboot of Zion. He starts to realise powers "outside" the Matrix to. This brings home beautifully the point that its all simulation, in order to make Neo able to make choices and thus become concious.

Re: Glitches Reloaded: Is the real world real?
posted on 07/04/2003 4:55 PM by blue_is_not_a_number

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Well... is Zion "real" or is it another artificial reality?


So far there seem to be three signs for it be another part of the matrix:

1. Agent Smith was able to "upload" at least his mindset onto Bane. However, this is (within the scifi genre) also imaginable with a "real" Zion, as for example in the movie "The Thirteenth Floor".

2. At the end, Neo was able to "feel" the approaching sentinels, and then to stop them. This might be related to the "connection" that Agent Smith claimed to be there between him and Neo, something that he thought Neo might be "aware" of. However, there don't seem to be any clues what this connection is "made of", and in scifi anything is possible.

3. When Neo and the crew leave from Zion, the kid brings him a spoon that one of the orphans gave him for Neo. This doesn't seem to be just a souvenir, as the kid says he had to swear to bring it to him, and the orphan didn't seem to be too sentimental. So it might have been a "challenge" to bend it, or the message that the statement "there is no spoon" also applies in the Zion world. Then the question is: where did the orphans go, having given the spoon to the kid.

Obviously, if the Zion world is just another part of the matrix, the programs (including the architect) don't want the humans to find out, at least they avoid giving them clues. Not even the Oracle seemed to give Neo any hints, but then, she either didn't know or didn't tell Neo about the things that he found out from the Architect, either. Unless this second matrix realm is just a technical way to deal with the anomalies the Architect was talking about, it might be a copy of the real situation, so as to avoid any doubts for those who "woke up" from the first matrix realm that the "new" world is now the "real" one.

Now they have a "choice" between two worlds, and that, with the associated struggles, might be all their mind needs.

However, it seems somehow unlikely to me that "Matrix Revolutions" will introduce a completly new third realm, the really real world (even if just a second "original" Zion), and all the fuzz about Zion (and the sentinels etc) seems somehow pointless if Zion is just another part of the matrix.

But then, who knows, except the Wachowski brothers? ;-)

Re: No!!!!Glitches in Reloaded
posted on 08/23/2003 9:59 AM by Z10n101

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

OK todays the day we have the plot ...all of you bashers take this!!!

The Origin of The Matrix: The first version of the matrix was created by the Architect to be the perfect world. The "primitive" minds of humans, however, could not accept the program. The supposed reasons for failure of the first matrix were sin and guilt. Based on these conclusions, the Architect created the second matrix which was based on chaos. He was still frustrated by failure. Then the Merovingian was created to investigate the reasons as to why the humans kept rejecting perfection. The Merovingian came to the conclusion that freewill should be eliminated from the system because perfection and freewill, as demonstrated by the monumental failure of the first matrix, were incompatible. The Architect then created the Oracle to find a solution without eliminating freewill. The Oracle concluded that choice is an illusion and that humans have never truly been free. She discovered that social structures such as government, church, corporations, and family control freewill without actually removing it thus creating the illusion of choice. Based on these conclusions, they set the third matrix at "the peak of your civilization" as the means of controlling free will. Civilization allows for the illusion of choice while supplying the necessary means to supress sin and guilt, the supposed causes of the flaws of the first matrix. However, by allowing the illusion of choice an anomaly eventually became created which could the destroy the matrix itself should the code not be reinserted into the matrix allowing a reboot and removing all problems until the next iteration of the anomaly. "Choice" would bring about the destruction of the matrix and so they relied on faith to save it. The Oracle had to continue inside the system to preserve faith and the belief in the one. This would allow for a continuous faith in the future of humanity from the anomaly and allow the system to continue rebooting. By using many systems of control they were able to keep everything in order and allow the matrix to continue despite one pontentially devastating flaw. The Merovingian chose exile after his purpose was served claiming that the argument as to the removal of choice was unsettled. He remains an exile waiting to prove that his theory of causality and the removal of freewill is the most efficient way to control the humans.

The Sixth Version: In the process of Neo "destroying" Smith, their codes are overwritten onto each other allowing for a connection between the two. Smith, facing deletion while returning to the source, chooses exile. His powers have been altered from either his encounter with the source or the overwriting process that occured with Neo. It is at this point irrelevant seeing as Smith is rapidly starting to have total control over the matrix by infecting it's every living inhabitant.

Now, ever wonder exactly what Smith is doing sneaking around all the time and showing up wherever Neo is? As for being in the back doors, there are two possibilites: either he's able to access them because of his viral code or as Morpheus says the agents hold all the keys.

Smith: "You look suprised to see me, AGAIN, Mr. Anderson. But that's the difference between us--I've been expecting you."

Neo: "What do you want Smith?"

Smith: "You haven't figured that out? Still using all the muscles except the one that matters. I want exactly what you want--I want everything."

We all remember the scene with the Architect--Neo was given two choices: The Matrix or The Source. Had he chosen the right door which leads to the source, his code would have been assimilated into the code for the matrix. The first five times it went perfectly. Neo, however, is different. He is connected to a certain someone that we all know and love; a man, a virus, who calls himself Smith. So, had Neo chosen the door on the right not only his code but Smith's viral code would have been assimilated into the matrix. If Smith infected the Source he would theoretically have control over the entire matrix and the machines. When Smith was about to be deleted he learned more about the nature of the matrix--more specifically the nature of the one or the anomaly. He knew about the choice given to the "Carrier of the Code" and with his new found abilities and hatred of his prison found a way to take advantage of the situation. Now, since Smith knew about the choice he knew that Neo would most likely choose Trinity. The only way to prevent him from choosing Trinity was to kill her. Smith-Bane wasn't going to kill Neo; he was going to kill Trinity. Had Trinity been dead he would be forced to choose the right door, giving Smith total control over the matrix.

Now, the Architect was watching over all of this. He knew what was going on and had no control over it. If Neo chose the door on the right, it would all have been over. Since the Architect is obviously a master at making new systems of control, he used the choice of the one to control Neo--to make him choose the door on the left. He could deal with losing the matrix again. They had lost crops before and they could do it again. They were willing to except that. Since the Architect had made a few matrices before it probably wouldn't take him that long to make a new one and there are already crops of humans being produced constantly. They'd have plenty of power again in no time. And you wondered why the Architect seemed so angry at Neo--he knows human psychology and he knew EXACTLY how to use Neo and how he would react.

So you see, Smith at the Burly Brawl and Smith in the hallway, both times he was trying to overwrite Neo. It obviously didn't work the first time. The second time, Morpheus was with him. He tried to take over Morpheus so then Neo would have no help and no way out. This attempt also failed. Smith's plan failed but as we see in Enter The Matrix he is still keeping himself busy.

Where shall we go now? Let's go with the Oracle. It is very clear to me now that she knew exactly what was going on. "You've already made the choice; you're here to try to understand why you made it." Neo doesn't realize how deep the systems of control go. What the Oracle was reffering to was the "choice" that the Architect was giving him. Now, some of us already knew this but look at it with this theory. It implies that she knows exactly why the Architect wants him to choose that door. Neo thinks it's to save Trinity when in fact it's to prevent Smith from overrunning the matrix. She decides that the only way to end the war is together. Machines and humans must work together. The door on the right would end with the elimination of both races.

Ok, next character. The Merovingian. What exactly was his motive? "What do all men with power want? More power." "I am a trafficer of information; I know everything I can." He knows about Smith and doesn't feel like losing his power.

Merovingian: "But this is not a reason; this is not a why. The Keymaker himself, his very nature, is a means; not an end. And so, to look for him is to be looking for a means to...do...what?"

Neo: "You know the answer to that question."

Merovingian: "But do you? You think you do but you do not."

Mero knows exactly what they want to use the Keymaker for. He probably thinks they will screw it up so he tells them no, they can't have him. Problem solved. This would keep Smith from having absolute power.

I remember somebody saying how dumb it was that the Twins were shooting at the back window and the trunk instead of the gas tank. I think Merovingian has the same interests as the Architect--to keep the matrix alive. As stated before, Merovingian doesn't feel like losing his seat of power so he has the Keymaker to prevent Neo from reaching the source and giving Smith the power. I think that the Merovingian also realizes that Trinity is very important to Neo's decision so he probably told his thugs not to fatally harm Trinity which would explain why they shoot at the back of the car and not the gas tank; they simply want to either keep or eliminate the Keymaker.

The Agents that we see shooting at Trinity during that same chase have a good reason for doing so without going against the theory. If they killed the driver of the car, it would either A) potentially kill the target (the Keymaker) by the car crashing or blowing up or B) make him a sitting duck. So if they could eliminate the possibility of Neo even meeting the Architect, why not go for it? Notice how it was only after she no longer possessed the Keymaker that they stopped chasing her.

Behind the Scenes: Faith, Hope, and Love. Morpheus represents faith. He "believes so blindly" and he never wavers in his beliefs. Trinity represents hope. Hope plays the most pivotal role in the trinity because it is the only way the prophecy can be fulfilled. Neo represents love. His undying love for Trinity is the reason for his "choices" and gives him hope. Hope is something that the previous Anomalies lacked and substituted it instead with faith in the future. Faith requires no action and hope without action becomes faith. Faith is the system of control that the machines had counted on and is the reason for the Oracle to exist. The Oracle is there to instill faith in the Zionites giving them the illusion of choice. She realizes that hope is the only way to overcome faith and plants the love between Neo and Trinity. She sees this as the only way to end the cycle. She is interested in only one thing: the future and she knows that the only way to get there is together. Neo has decided to make the prophecy come true.

The following with astericks in front of them are facts.

*The clock at the Merovingian's restaurant reads exactly 12 PM.
*The clock at the security guards office reads exactly 12 AM.
*12 hours around a clock face makes a full circle
*101 in binary is 5
*314 seconds could refer to pi, which is just over 5
*Pi is needed to make a circle
*At the Oracle's abandoned apartment there is a Pi sign with a circle around and a line through it, meaning "No Pi"
*The Matrix is cyclic
*The Matrix is currently in it's 6th cycle
*Spoon Boy has 5 bent spoons laying before him in M1 and Neo bends the sixth spoon but returns it to it's normal position.
*The date 2-2-2003 appears in The Animatrix episode, Beyond.

Conclusion: These facts seem to point to Neo being "The" One. There are many references to 5 and a "No Pi" sign which, to me, anyways seem to point to the conclusion that the matrix will no longer be cyclic. If it is not cyclic, that means that Neo has not entered the source which means he either a) is dead. b) defeated the machines or c) has decided to call a truce with the machines. Seeing as The Matrix Online states that The Matrix lives on after The Matrix Revolutions and the date for Beyond is well beyond any point in the movies, it seems that the conclusion of Revolutions can be either narrowed down to choice A or C. A and C could be a combonation as well with Neo compromising like the scriptment says.

Credit goes to Ratio, IaMtHeMaTrIx, Spyros, and myself for this theory. Guys, if I missed anything pm it to me and I'll add it in. No need to make THIS thread 30 pages long.

Re: No!!!!Glitches in Reloaded
posted on 12/08/2003 6:09 PM by timventura

[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

To Z10n101:

We know now that there is no "blue Matrix" -- not unless they make another trilogy at least. I wasn't a big fan of that idea, although I feel compelled to follow up on a couple of things:

First, you cannot act like you've "won a debate" against anybody by waiting until you have a script for the sequel. In fact, it kind of shows that you're unable to win a debate other than by cheating (sorry, but undeniably true).

Second, since the suppositions about the Matrix in previous postings came out before the Reloaded or Revolutions was released, the arguments in them must be considered without the inclusion of these further scripts......

Third, you weren't arguing against me in the first place (it would appear that I am new to this chain), but I don't want to here criticism on any of the things that I'd previously written about the Matrix based on new knowledge from the 2nd or 3rd movie.

Part of a gentlemanly debate is following the rules of fair conduct, and I would have to say that jumping in the day after a script is released and screaming "this is how it is" seems to be about as juvenile as it gets.

Again, sorry for the ill-will, but the Kurzweil-site supposedly has intellectual merits above and beyond the Matrix fan-site, where such arguments and tactics are expected behaviour.

Tim

Two questions
posted on 11/04/2003 10:09 AM by Matt Bridges

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

I just rented Reloaded to watch it one last time before Revolutions comes out tomorrow. Peter, I read your article in the afternoon before I watched it, and so I had some of your ideas in mind. I have two questions:

1) If machines cannot make free choices/do not have free will, how can some programs 'choose' exile over deletion? Is this choice somehow not an exercise in free will?

2) What motivation do the agents have for trying to kill the keymaker in the highway scene? If the survival of the matrix depends on Neo reaching the source and rebooting it, why would the agents impede Neo's progress? What motivation does the Merovingian have for trying to stop Neo? In other words, if the machines need Neo to reach the source in order to keep the matrix running/reboot, why are they all getting in his way?

Thanks, your article was certainly an interesting read.

Re: Two questions
posted on 11/04/2003 12:59 PM by radmail

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

Another question is ' do any of us possess true free will or are all of our beliefs, emotions and thus choices determined by our innate traits and experience'? There are many sides to the Free will vs Determinism debate... I tend to think that we are subject to our innate traits and experience, but also have free will (ironically as part of this deterministic process) which can kind of influence our character. Sorry for being confusing and contradictory... I can't really get my head around it...

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 11/01/2005 3:10 PM by Phantom

 [Top]
[Mind·X]
[Reply to this post]

I like the metaphor of printing. If you have a black-ink printing press, then you will only ever get back-and-white pictures from it. No matter how complex the pictures, we will not suddenly find colours 'emerging' from them. To get a coloured picture out, we must put coloured ink in. Likewise, to have consciousness in the world, we must put consciousnes in to begin with.


Color does not exist physically, only as a result of sub-conscious interpretation of a set of physical properties, through the physical and mental filters enclosing an individual.

Spin your black-and-white picture and you will perceive color, as the pulse of alternating black and white begins to emulate the frequencies of 'color'.

Consciousness is required for black-and-white as well as color, as both are characteristics of the same concept.

Of course all those 'other' theories end up in the same place as well..

Re: Glitches Reloaded
posted on 05/19/2006 2:37 PM by Hererinc

Why you are wrong. (Brief)

I read this article and got down to the philosophical argument part of the piece and had to stop reading. This is not a personal attack but an opinion on your descriptions of the uses of the technology in the movies. You make some great comparisons to technologies in you ideas on how it's related to The Matrix, but often some of your explanations are just left to, because someone looked a certain way in the movie or because of an action in the film. This is where as a reader and film maker I get very upset. I first believe your ideas about a Meta-Matrix are wrong. A far as basing the movies as they are your belief on that point is left to speculation based on the events presented. You often just brush over or simply disregard many of the other option for available explanation. First about you clues for the Meta- Matrix. Is Neo's ability to touch the sentinels and disengage them. Couldn't it be probable that he was accessing a part of the sentinels that existed in the Matrix itself. That he himself was 'jacking' into the matrix and attacking them from there, which is why he got projected into the train construct, because while attacking the machines via this port he either got router somewhere else or lost. Some other of your arguments don't make much sense either because you rely so heavily upon a concrete explanation of the world. The Matrix itself was a simulated reality based on impulses from the carriers brain projected onto a simulated world. Your argument with mouse and the lady in red makes no sense. As I saw it the implication in the film was that after seeing a picture of her in the 'real' world or what you would call meta-matrix he then programmed her specs into the matrix construct that Morpheus and Neo where in. There is also and connection you don't mention, is the mind and body connection that is one of the main proponents of the film. The whole idea is that your brain can project the thought of death on your real body because you mind is that strong. The simulation of the matrix feels so real, the immersion of it is so real that dying there tells you brain its dead and because it connects to your body in the real world convinces you that you have died. You do make a mind body connection in your obvious scientific explanation of how they pulled off the integration of the brain to accept the matrix, but my explanation relies more on a program being feed to your like a computer program or a game you play.

I could go on for hours on many more holes. I do admire the fact that you decided to put so much work into the article but I my anger is rooted in a love for the idea that manifest through the films.

By the way I stumbled on this site and just found your article, so if its old and no one reads it so be it, but I had to post.
